group can be specified instead of a watch The group is referenced by a variable of type I watchgroup Watch groups must be created before they are used Attempting to use a watch group that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watch groups must be destroyed when no longer useful The watches themselves are not only the grouping of them Failure to destroy watch groups can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watchgroup creates a new watch group IP o B destroy_watchgroup destroys a watch and accept several forms of I watch The forms an array of watches can be specified by an array constructor in the calling for w3 call this can not be used in routines where I watch has intent OUT or intent because the array constructor is actually an not a list of the variables Currently this includes the routines B create_watch and B destroy_watch Most M_StopWatch subroutines take I clock as or or can be an array of such character strings to specify more than one clock Since I clock is always intent an array of clock types can be built with an array constructor note that Fortran requires all character strings in such a construction to have the same length Thus sys and cpu should be padded with a as cpu If the optional argument I clock is the current set of default clocks is used The set of default clocks is set with B option_stopwatch and initially consists of all available clocks A M_StopWatch watch is operated on by subroutine calls that correspond to the actions performed with a common stop watch The basic operation of a watch involves starting stopping and resetting it to IP o B start_watch starts an idle like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B stop_watch stops a running like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B reset_watch sets the clocks on a watch like the Reset button on a stop watch LP Of running a stop watch is of little use unless you can see what it says IP o B read_watch returns the current clock value of a like looking at the display of a stop watch IP o B print_watch prints the current clock value of a watch to an output device To push the analogy to the imagine a stop watch with a printer attached to it LP The routine B read_watch is a function subroutine The result is either a array of rank or array of rank two depending on whether I watch and I clock are scalars or arrays When measuring CPU it is often desirable to not include the time used by certain parts of the such as printing or graphics In a you might not know which of the clocks are currently so you can not simply stop them before the I O and start them up again after the I O For M_StopWatch provides the pause function IP o B pause_watch temporarily suspend the running watches IP o B end_pause_watch resume suspended watches LP Besides B create_watchgroup and B there are two operations that can be performed on I watchgroup to determine the current value of these and to determine system dependent values of the implementation IP o B option_stopwatch sets options within M_StopWatch IP o B inquiry_stopwatch returns values of options and system dependent values LP See BR if returns a status code The code is the sum of the values listed below Errors can also be determined through printed error messages An error message will be printed to a specified I O so you should set I print_errors to TRUE if you have trouble determining the cause of the error All errors are non fatal If I abort_errors is the program will terminate on an error condition Otherwise
 
execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating them
 
execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating and destroying local variable watches and groups before returning from a subroutine IP Error occurred while deallocating memory This error occurs if the Fortran B deallocate statement returns a nonzero status while deallocating temporary memory used for an array or group of watches The operation is performed
 
execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating and destroying local variable watches and groups before returning from a subroutine IP Error occurred while deallocating memory This error occurs if the Fortran B deallocate statement returns a nonzero status while deallocating temporary memory used for an array or group of watches The operation is but be aware that other problems could develop as a result of the deallocate error IP Illegal output form This error occurs in B option_stopwatch or B print_watch if the given print format is not one of the valid the following problems may arise
 
execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating and destroying local variable watches and groups before returning from a subroutine IP Error occurred while deallocating memory This error occurs if the Fortran B deallocate statement returns a nonzero status while deallocating temporary memory used for an array or group of watches The operation is but be aware that other problems could develop as a result of the deallocate error IP Illegal output form This error occurs in B option_stopwatch or B print_watch if the given print format is not one of the valid the following problems may the character strings in an array constructor must all have the same length Pad three letter clock names with a blank on the right to make a four character string
 
execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating and destroying local variable watches and groups before returning from a subroutine IP Error occurred while deallocating memory This error occurs if the Fortran B deallocate statement returns a nonzero status while deallocating temporary memory used for an array or group of watches The operation is but be aware that other problems could develop as a result of the deallocate error IP Illegal output form This error occurs in B option_stopwatch or B print_watch if the given print format is not one of the valid the following problems may the character strings in an array constructor must all have the same length Pad three letter clock names with a blank on the right to make a four character for and pad watch names so they all have the same watch has intent OUT or so you cannot use an array constructor as an actual argument to construct an array of watches Some compilers will recognize this as a compile time but will generate an obscure error message
 
execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating and destroying local variable watches and groups before returning from a subroutine IP Error occurred while deallocating memory This error occurs if the Fortran B deallocate statement returns a nonzero status while deallocating temporary memory used for an array or group of watches The operation is but be aware that other problems could develop as a result of the deallocate error IP Illegal output form This error occurs in B option_stopwatch or B print_watch if the given print format is not one of the valid the following problems may the character strings in an array constructor must all have the same length Pad three letter clock names with a blank on the right to make a four character for and pad watch names so they all have the same watch has intent OUT or so you cannot use an array constructor as an actual argument to construct an array of watches Some compilers will recognize this as a compile time but will generate an obscure error such as no specific match for generic name SH EXAMPLE nf ! The following times are measured
 
 __pad0__
 
 public
 

Function Documentation

◆ group()

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME easy to use means of measuring execution time It supports the wall CPU and a breakdown of the CPU clock into user and system times It returns all times in seconds It provides a simple means of determining which clocks are and the precision of those clocks M_StopWatch is used by instrumenting your code with subroutine calls that mimic the operation of a stop watch The primary routines are B and B print_watch M_StopWatch supports multiple and provides the concept of watch groups to allow functions to operate on multiple watches simultaneously SH DESCRIPTION The entities in M_StopWatch that have public accessibility are two derived types and fifteen i must contain the statement use M_stopwatch The derived types but the internals of the type are private Any operations performed on a variable of one of these types must be performed by one of the M_StopWatch subroutines This man page in general the operations that can be performed by the M_StopWatch subroutines The formal interfaces and detailed descriptions of the routines can be found in the individual man pages A watch is a variable declared to be of type I watchtype It can be passed to subroutines as an actual argument or through modules like any Fortran but can only be operated on by the M_StopWatch subroutines Watches must be created by subroutine B create_watch before they are used Attempting to use a watch that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watches must be destroyed when no longer useful For consider a local variable of type I watchtype in a subroutine Since the contents of a local variable are lost when the subroutine the watch should be destroyed before returning to the calling program Failure to destroy watches can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watch creates a watch IP o B destroy_watch destroys a watch LP Watches can optionally be given a I in B create_watch This name is used in error messages and B print_watch to identify the watch in the printed output Different applications demand different definitions of time M_StopWatch supports four clocks in each with each clock measuring a different concept of time All of them measure time in seconds IP o user the amount of CPU time used by the user s program IP o sys the amount of CPU time used by the system in support of the user s program IP o cpu the total CPU i user sys IP o wall the wall clock i elapsed real time LP It is not required that all clocks be used A watch can be created with any combination of the four clocks You can also specify a set of I default clocks to be used whenever the clocks are not explicitly determined Since Fortran does not contain an intrinsic function for CPU the implementation of the sys and user clocks is system dependent Some implementations may support only cpu and not user and sys Some implementations may support only wall Since the Fortran standard requires the existence of a B system_clock but does not require that it provide clock it is possible that some implementations might not support wall Clock availability can be determined by B inquiry_stopwatch Unavailable clocks will automatically be removed from the set of default but if a clock that is not available is explicitly a warning message will be generated M_StopWatch supports multiple watches simultaneously Often it is useful to perform the same operation on several watches This is essential for correct operation of B pause_watch and B and can also be convenient for procedures like B and B reset_watch To facilitate M_StopWatch supports the concept of I watch groups When calling a M_StopWatch a watch group can be specified instead of a watch The group is referenced by a variable of type I watchgroup Watch groups must be created before they are used Attempting to use a watch group that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watch groups must be destroyed when no longer useful The watches themselves are not only the grouping of them Failure to destroy watch groups can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watchgroup creates a new watch group IP o B destroy_watchgroup destroys a watch group ( but not the watches in the  group)

◆ inquiry_stopwatch()

execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR inquiry_stopwatch ( 3  )

◆ length()

execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating and destroying local variable watches and groups before returning from a subroutine IP Error occurred while deallocating memory This error occurs if the Fortran B deallocate statement returns a nonzero status while deallocating temporary memory used for an array or group of watches The operation is but be aware that other problems could develop as a result of the deallocate error IP Illegal output form This error occurs in B option_stopwatch or B print_watch if the given print format is not one of the valid the following problems may the character strings in an array constructor must all have the same length Pad three letter clock names with a blank on the right to make a four character for and pad watch names so they all have the same length ( within an array  constructor)

◆ M_stopwatch()

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME M_stopwatch ( 3f  )

◆ name()

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME easy to use means of measuring execution time It supports the wall CPU and a breakdown of the CPU clock into user and system times It returns all times in seconds It provides a simple means of determining which clocks are and the precision of those clocks M_StopWatch is used by instrumenting your code with subroutine calls that mimic the operation of a stop watch The primary routines are B and B print_watch M_StopWatch supports multiple and provides the concept of watch groups to allow functions to operate on multiple watches simultaneously SH DESCRIPTION The entities in M_StopWatch that have public accessibility are two derived types and fifteen i must contain the statement use M_stopwatch The derived types but the internals of the type are private Any operations performed on a variable of one of these types must be performed by one of the M_StopWatch subroutines This man page in general the operations that can be performed by the M_StopWatch subroutines The formal interfaces and detailed descriptions of the routines can be found in the individual man pages A watch is a variable declared to be of type I watchtype It can be passed to subroutines as an actual argument or through modules like any Fortran but can only be operated on by the M_StopWatch subroutines Watches must be created by subroutine B create_watch before they are used Attempting to use a watch that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watches must be destroyed when no longer useful For consider a local variable of type I watchtype in a subroutine Since the contents of a local variable are lost when the subroutine the watch should be destroyed before returning to the calling program Failure to destroy watches can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watch creates a watch IP o B destroy_watch destroys a watch LP Watches can optionally be given a name ( up to 132  characters)

execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the state ( running  ,
stopped  ,
etc.   
)

◆ strings()

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME easy to use means of measuring execution time It supports the wall CPU and a breakdown of the CPU clock into user and system times It returns all times in seconds It provides a simple means of determining which clocks are and the precision of those clocks M_StopWatch is used by instrumenting your code with subroutine calls that mimic the operation of a stop watch The primary routines are B and B print_watch M_StopWatch supports multiple and provides the concept of watch groups to allow functions to operate on multiple watches simultaneously SH DESCRIPTION The entities in M_StopWatch that have public accessibility are two derived types and fifteen subroutines ( one of which is a function  subroutine)

◆ the()

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME easy to use means of measuring execution time It supports the wall CPU and a breakdown of the CPU clock into user and system times It returns all times in seconds It provides a simple means of determining which clocks are and the precision of those clocks M_StopWatch is used by instrumenting your code with subroutine calls that mimic the operation of a stop watch The primary routines are B and B print_watch M_StopWatch supports multiple and provides the concept of watch groups to allow functions to operate on multiple watches simultaneously SH DESCRIPTION The entities in M_StopWatch that have public accessibility are two derived types and fifteen i must contain the statement use M_stopwatch The derived types but the internals of the type are private Any operations performed on a variable of one of these types must be performed by one of the M_StopWatch subroutines This man page in general the operations that can be performed by the M_StopWatch subroutines The formal interfaces and detailed descriptions of the routines can be found in the individual man pages A watch is a variable declared to be of type I watchtype It can be passed to subroutines as an actual argument or through modules like any Fortran but can only be operated on by the M_StopWatch subroutines Watches must be created by subroutine B create_watch before they are used Attempting to use a watch that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watches must be destroyed when no longer useful For consider a local variable of type I watchtype in a subroutine Since the contents of a local variable are lost when the subroutine the watch should be destroyed before returning to the calling program Failure to destroy watches can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watch creates a watch IP o B destroy_watch destroys a watch LP Watches can optionally be given a I in B create_watch This name is used in error messages and B print_watch to identify the watch in the printed output Different applications demand different definitions of time M_StopWatch supports four clocks in each with each clock measuring a different concept of time All of them measure time in seconds IP o user the amount of CPU time used by the user s program IP o sys the amount of CPU time used by the system in support of the user s program IP o cpu the total CPU i user sys IP o wall the wall clock i elapsed real time LP It is not required that all clocks be used A watch can be created with any combination of the four clocks You can also specify a set of I default clocks to be used whenever the clocks are not explicitly might not support wall Clock availability can be determined by B inquiry_stopwatch Unavailable clocks will automatically be removed from the set of default but if a clock that is not available is explicitly a warning message will be generated M_StopWatch supports multiple watches simultaneously Often it is useful to perform the same operation on several watches This is essential for correct operation of B pause_watch and B and can also be convenient for procedures like B and B reset_watch To facilitate M_StopWatch supports the concept of I watch groups When calling a M_StopWatch a watch group can be specified instead of a watch The group is referenced by a variable of type I watchgroup Watch groups must be created before they are used Attempting to use a watch group that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watch groups must be destroyed when no longer useful The watches themselves are not only the grouping of them Failure to destroy watch groups can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watchgroup creates a new watch group IP o B destroy_watchgroup destroys a watch and accept several forms of I watch The forms an array of watches can be specified by an array constructor in the calling for w3 call this can not be used in routines where I watch has intent OUT or intent because the array constructor is actually an not a list of the variables Currently this includes the routines B create_watch and B destroy_watch Most M_StopWatch subroutines take I clock as the ( optional  )

◆ TRUE()

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME easy to use means of measuring execution time It supports the wall CPU and a breakdown of the CPU clock into user and system times It returns all times in seconds It provides a simple means of determining which clocks are and the precision of those clocks M_StopWatch is used by instrumenting your code with subroutine calls that mimic the operation of a stop watch The primary routines are B and B print_watch M_StopWatch supports multiple and provides the concept of watch groups to allow functions to operate on multiple watches simultaneously SH DESCRIPTION The entities in M_StopWatch that have public accessibility are two derived types and fifteen i must contain the statement use M_stopwatch The derived types but the internals of the type are private Any operations performed on a variable of one of these types must be performed by one of the M_StopWatch subroutines This man page in general the operations that can be performed by the M_StopWatch subroutines The formal interfaces and detailed descriptions of the routines can be found in the individual man pages A watch is a variable declared to be of type I watchtype It can be passed to subroutines as an actual argument or through modules like any Fortran but can only be operated on by the M_StopWatch subroutines Watches must be created by subroutine B create_watch before they are used Attempting to use a watch that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watches must be destroyed when no longer useful For consider a local variable of type I watchtype in a subroutine Since the contents of a local variable are lost when the subroutine the watch should be destroyed before returning to the calling program Failure to destroy watches can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watch creates a watch IP o B destroy_watch destroys a watch LP Watches can optionally be given a I in B create_watch This name is used in error messages and B print_watch to identify the watch in the printed output Different applications demand different definitions of time M_StopWatch supports four clocks in each with each clock measuring a different concept of time All of them measure time in seconds IP o user the amount of CPU time used by the user s program IP o sys the amount of CPU time used by the system in support of the user s program IP o cpu the total CPU i user sys IP o wall the wall clock i elapsed real time LP It is not required that all clocks be used A watch can be created with any combination of the four clocks You can also specify a set of I default clocks to be used whenever the clocks are not explicitly determined Since Fortran does not contain an intrinsic function for CPU the implementation of the sys and user clocks is system dependent Some implementations may support only cpu and not user and sys Some implementations may support only wall Since the Fortran standard requires the existence of a B system_clock but does not require that it provide clock it is possible that some implementations might not support wall Clock availability can be determined by B inquiry_stopwatch Unavailable clocks will automatically be removed from the set of default but if a clock that is not available is explicitly a warning message will be generated M_StopWatch supports multiple watches simultaneously Often it is useful to perform the same operation on several watches This is essential for correct operation of B pause_watch and B and can also be convenient for procedures like B and B reset_watch To facilitate M_StopWatch supports the concept of I watch groups When calling a M_StopWatch a watch group can be specified instead of a watch The group is referenced by a variable of type I watchgroup Watch groups must be created before they are used Attempting to use a watch group that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watch groups must be destroyed when no longer useful The watches themselves are not only the grouping of them Failure to destroy watch groups can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watchgroup creates a new watch group IP o B destroy_watchgroup destroys a watch and accept several forms of I watch The forms an array of watches can be specified by an array constructor in the calling for w3 call this can not be used in routines where I watch has intent OUT or intent because the array constructor is actually an not a list of the variables Currently this includes the routines B create_watch and B destroy_watch Most M_StopWatch subroutines take I clock as or or can be an array of such character strings to specify more than one clock Since I clock is always intent an array of clock types can be built with an array constructor note that Fortran requires all character strings in such a construction to have the same length Thus sys and cpu should be padded with a as cpu If the optional argument I clock is the current set of default clocks is used The set of default clocks is set with B option_stopwatch and initially consists of all available clocks A M_StopWatch watch is operated on by subroutine calls that correspond to the actions performed with a common stop watch The basic operation of a watch involves starting stopping and resetting it to IP o B start_watch starts an idle like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B stop_watch stops a running like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B reset_watch sets the clocks on a watch like the Reset button on a stop watch LP Of running a stop watch is of little use unless you can see what it says IP o B read_watch returns the current clock value of a like looking at the display of a stop watch IP o B print_watch prints the current clock value of a watch to an output device To push the analogy to the imagine a stop watch with a printer attached to it LP The routine B read_watch is a function subroutine The result is either a array of rank or array of rank two depending on whether I watch and I clock are scalars or arrays When measuring CPU it is often desirable to not include the time used by certain parts of the such as printing or graphics In a you might not know which of the clocks are currently so you can not simply stop them before the I O and start them up again after the I O For M_StopWatch provides the pause function IP o B pause_watch temporarily suspend the running watches IP o B end_pause_watch resume suspended watches LP Besides B create_watchgroup and B there are two operations that can be performed on I watchgroup to determine the current value of these and to determine system dependent values of the implementation IP o B option_stopwatch sets options within M_StopWatch IP o B inquiry_stopwatch returns values of options and system dependent values LP See BR if returns a status code The code is the sum of the values listed below Errors can also be determined through printed error messages An error message will be printed to a specified I O so you should set I print_errors to TRUE if you have trouble determining the cause of the error All errors are non fatal If I abort_errors is TRUE ( default is  FALSE)

◆ type()

global var type ( watchgroup  )

◆ unit()

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME easy to use means of measuring execution time It supports the wall CPU and a breakdown of the CPU clock into user and system times It returns all times in seconds It provides a simple means of determining which clocks are and the precision of those clocks M_StopWatch is used by instrumenting your code with subroutine calls that mimic the operation of a stop watch The primary routines are B and B print_watch M_StopWatch supports multiple and provides the concept of watch groups to allow functions to operate on multiple watches simultaneously SH DESCRIPTION The entities in M_StopWatch that have public accessibility are two derived types and fifteen i must contain the statement use M_stopwatch The derived types but the internals of the type are private Any operations performed on a variable of one of these types must be performed by one of the M_StopWatch subroutines This man page in general the operations that can be performed by the M_StopWatch subroutines The formal interfaces and detailed descriptions of the routines can be found in the individual man pages A watch is a variable declared to be of type I watchtype It can be passed to subroutines as an actual argument or through modules like any Fortran but can only be operated on by the M_StopWatch subroutines Watches must be created by subroutine B create_watch before they are used Attempting to use a watch that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watches must be destroyed when no longer useful For consider a local variable of type I watchtype in a subroutine Since the contents of a local variable are lost when the subroutine the watch should be destroyed before returning to the calling program Failure to destroy watches can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watch creates a watch IP o B destroy_watch destroys a watch LP Watches can optionally be given a I in B create_watch This name is used in error messages and B print_watch to identify the watch in the printed output Different applications demand different definitions of time M_StopWatch supports four clocks in each with each clock measuring a different concept of time All of them measure time in seconds IP o user the amount of CPU time used by the user s program IP o sys the amount of CPU time used by the system in support of the user s program IP o cpu the total CPU i user sys IP o wall the wall clock i elapsed real time LP It is not required that all clocks be used A watch can be created with any combination of the four clocks You can also specify a set of I default clocks to be used whenever the clocks are not explicitly determined Since Fortran does not contain an intrinsic function for CPU the implementation of the sys and user clocks is system dependent Some implementations may support only cpu and not user and sys Some implementations may support only wall Since the Fortran standard requires the existence of a B system_clock but does not require that it provide clock it is possible that some implementations might not support wall Clock availability can be determined by B inquiry_stopwatch Unavailable clocks will automatically be removed from the set of default but if a clock that is not available is explicitly a warning message will be generated M_StopWatch supports multiple watches simultaneously Often it is useful to perform the same operation on several watches This is essential for correct operation of B pause_watch and B and can also be convenient for procedures like B and B reset_watch To facilitate M_StopWatch supports the concept of I watch groups When calling a M_StopWatch a watch group can be specified instead of a watch The group is referenced by a variable of type I watchgroup Watch groups must be created before they are used Attempting to use a watch group that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watch groups must be destroyed when no longer useful The watches themselves are not only the grouping of them Failure to destroy watch groups can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watchgroup creates a new watch group IP o B destroy_watchgroup destroys a watch and accept several forms of I watch The forms an array of watches can be specified by an array constructor in the calling for w3 call this can not be used in routines where I watch has intent OUT or intent because the array constructor is actually an not a list of the variables Currently this includes the routines B create_watch and B destroy_watch Most M_StopWatch subroutines take I clock as or or can be an array of such character strings to specify more than one clock Since I clock is always intent an array of clock types can be built with an array constructor note that Fortran requires all character strings in such a construction to have the same length Thus sys and cpu should be padded with a as cpu If the optional argument I clock is the current set of default clocks is used The set of default clocks is set with B option_stopwatch and initially consists of all available clocks A M_StopWatch watch is operated on by subroutine calls that correspond to the actions performed with a common stop watch The basic operation of a watch involves starting stopping and resetting it to IP o B start_watch starts an idle like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B stop_watch stops a running like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B reset_watch sets the clocks on a watch like the Reset button on a stop watch LP Of running a stop watch is of little use unless you can see what it says IP o B read_watch returns the current clock value of a like looking at the display of a stop watch IP o B print_watch prints the current clock value of a watch to an output device To push the analogy to the imagine a stop watch with a printer attached to it LP The routine B read_watch is a function subroutine The result is either a array of rank or array of rank two depending on whether I watch and I clock are scalars or arrays When measuring CPU it is often desirable to not include the time used by certain parts of the such as printing or graphics In a you might not know which of the clocks are currently so you can not simply stop them before the I O and start them up again after the I O For M_StopWatch provides the pause function IP o B pause_watch temporarily suspend the running watches IP o B end_pause_watch resume suspended watches LP Besides B create_watchgroup and B there are two operations that can be performed on I watchgroup to determine the current value of these and to determine system dependent values of the implementation IP o B option_stopwatch sets options within M_StopWatch IP o B inquiry_stopwatch returns values of options and system dependent values LP See BR if returns a status code The code is the sum of the values listed below Errors can also be determined through printed error messages An error message will be printed to a specified I O unit ( unit 6 by  default)

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME easy to use means of measuring execution time It supports the wall CPU and a breakdown of the CPU clock into user and system times It returns all times in seconds It provides a simple means of determining which clocks are and the precision of those clocks M_StopWatch is used by instrumenting your code with subroutine calls that mimic the operation of a stop watch The primary routines are B and B print_watch M_StopWatch supports multiple and provides the concept of watch groups to allow functions to operate on multiple watches simultaneously SH DESCRIPTION The entities in M_StopWatch that have public accessibility are two derived types and fifteen i must contain the statement use M_stopwatch The derived types but the internals of the type are private Any operations performed on a variable of one of these types must be performed by one of the M_StopWatch subroutines This man page in general the operations that can be performed by the M_StopWatch subroutines The formal interfaces and detailed descriptions of the routines can be found in the individual man pages A watch is a variable declared to be of type I watchtype It can be passed to subroutines as an actual argument or through modules like any Fortran but can only be operated on by the M_StopWatch subroutines Watches must be created by subroutine B create_watch before they are used Attempting to use a watch that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watches must be destroyed when no longer useful For consider a local variable of type I watchtype in a subroutine Since the contents of a local variable are lost when the subroutine the watch should be destroyed before returning to the calling program Failure to destroy watches can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watch creates a watch IP o B destroy_watch destroys a watch LP Watches can optionally be given a I in B create_watch This name is used in error messages and B print_watch to identify the watch in the printed output Different applications demand different definitions of time M_StopWatch supports four clocks in each with each clock measuring a different concept of time All of them measure time in seconds IP o user the amount of CPU time used by the user s program IP o sys the amount of CPU time used by the system in support of the user s program IP o cpu the total CPU i user sys IP o wall the wall clock i elapsed real time LP It is not required that all clocks be used A watch can be created with any combination of the four clocks You can also specify a set of I default clocks to be used whenever the clocks are not explicitly determined Since Fortran does not contain an intrinsic function for CPU the implementation of the sys and user clocks is system dependent Some implementations may support only cpu and not user and sys Some implementations may support only wall Since the Fortran standard requires the existence of a B system_clock but does not require that it provide clock it is possible that some implementations might not support wall Clock availability can be determined by B inquiry_stopwatch Unavailable clocks will automatically be removed from the set of default but if a clock that is not available is explicitly a warning message will be generated M_StopWatch supports multiple watches simultaneously Often it is useful to perform the same operation on several watches This is essential for correct operation of B pause_watch and B and can also be convenient for procedures like B and B reset_watch To facilitate M_StopWatch supports the concept of I watch groups When calling a M_StopWatch a watch group can be specified instead of a watch The group is referenced by a variable of type I watchgroup Watch groups must be created before they are used Attempting to use a watch group that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watch groups must be destroyed when no longer useful The watches themselves are not only the grouping of them Failure to destroy watch groups can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watchgroup creates a new watch group IP o B destroy_watchgroup destroys a watch and accept several forms of I watch The forms an array of watches can be specified by an array constructor in the calling for w3 call this can not be used in routines where I watch has intent OUT or intent because the array constructor is actually an not a list of the variables Currently this includes the routines B create_watch and B destroy_watch Most M_StopWatch subroutines take I clock as or or can be an array of such character strings to specify more than one clock Since I clock is always intent an array of clock types can be built with an array constructor note that Fortran requires all character strings in such a construction to have the same length Thus sys and cpu should be padded with a as cpu If the optional argument I clock is the current set of default clocks is used The set of default clocks is set with B option_stopwatch and initially consists of all available clocks A M_StopWatch watch is operated on by subroutine calls that correspond to the actions performed with a common stop watch The basic operation of a watch involves starting stopping and resetting it to IP o B start_watch starts an idle like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B stop_watch stops a running like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B reset_watch sets the clocks on a watch like the Reset button on a stop watch LP Of running a stop watch is of little use unless you can see what it says IP o B read_watch returns the current clock value of a like looking at the display of a stop watch IP o B print_watch prints the current clock value of a watch to an output device To push the analogy to the imagine a stop watch with a printer attached to it LP The routine B read_watch is a function subroutine The result is either a array of rank or array of rank two depending on whether I watch and I clock are scalars or arrays When measuring CPU it is often desirable to not include the time used by certain parts of the such as printing or graphics In a you might not know which of the clocks are currently so you can not simply stop them before the I O and start them up again after the I O For M_StopWatch provides the pause function IP o B pause_watch temporarily suspend the running watches IP o B end_pause_watch resume suspended watches LP Besides B create_watchgroup and B there are two operations that can be performed on I watchgroup to determine the current value of these and to determine system dependent values of the implementation IP o B option_stopwatch sets options within M_StopWatch IP o B inquiry_stopwatch returns values of options and system dependent values LP See BR if returns a status code The code is the sum of the values listed below Errors can also be determined through printed error messages An error message will be printed to a specified I O so you should set I print_errors to TRUE if you have trouble determining the cause of the error All errors are non fatal If I abort_errors is the program will terminate on an error condition the program will continue execution but the requested operation will not be performed See BR abort_errors and I O units The relevant status codes and messages are

◆ arise

execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating and destroying local variable watches and groups before returning from a subroutine IP Error occurred while deallocating memory This error occurs if the Fortran B deallocate statement returns a nonzero status while deallocating temporary memory used for an array or group of watches The operation is but be aware that other problems could develop as a result of the deallocate error IP Illegal output form This error occurs in B option_stopwatch or B print_watch if the given print format is not one of the valid the following problems may arise

◆ available

The watches themselves are not only the grouping of them Failure to destroy watch groups can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watchgroup creates a new watch group IP o B destroy_watchgroup destroys a watch and accept several forms of I watch The forms an array of watches can be specified by an array constructor in the calling for w3 call this can not be used in routines where I watch has intent OUT or intent because the array constructor is actually an not a list of the variables Currently this includes the routines B create_watch and B destroy_watch Most M_StopWatch subroutines take I clock as or or can be an array of such character strings to specify more than one clock Since I clock is always intent an array of clock types can be built with an array constructor note that Fortran requires all character strings in such a construction to have the same length Thus sys and cpu should be padded with a as cpu If the optional argument I clock is the current set of default clocks is used The set of default clocks is set with B option_stopwatch and initially consists of all available clocks A M_StopWatch watch is operated on by subroutine calls that correspond to the actions performed with a common stop watch The basic operation of a watch involves starting stopping and resetting it to IP o B start_watch starts an idle like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B stop_watch stops a running like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B reset_watch sets the clocks on a watch like the Reset button on a stop watch LP Of running a stop watch is of little use unless you can see what it says IP o B read_watch returns the current clock value of a like looking at the display of a stop watch IP o B print_watch prints the current clock value of a watch to an output device To push the analogy to the imagine a stop watch with a printer attached to it LP The routine B read_watch is a function subroutine The result is either a array of rank or array of rank two depending on whether I watch and I clock are scalars or arrays When measuring CPU it is often desirable to not include the time used by certain parts of the code

◆ course

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME easy to use means of measuring execution time It supports the wall CPU and a breakdown of the CPU clock into user and system times It returns all times in seconds It provides a simple means of determining which clocks are and the precision of those clocks M_StopWatch is used by instrumenting your code with subroutine calls that mimic the operation of a stop watch The primary routines are B and B print_watch M_StopWatch supports multiple and provides the concept of watch groups to allow functions to operate on multiple watches simultaneously SH DESCRIPTION The entities in M_StopWatch that have public accessibility are two derived types and fifteen i must contain the statement use M_stopwatch The derived types but the internals of the type are private Any operations performed on a variable of one of these types must be performed by one of the M_StopWatch subroutines This man page in general the operations that can be performed by the M_StopWatch subroutines The formal interfaces and detailed descriptions of the routines can be found in the individual man pages A watch is a variable declared to be of type I watchtype It can be passed to subroutines as an actual argument or through modules like any Fortran but can only be operated on by the M_StopWatch subroutines Watches must be created by subroutine B create_watch before they are used Attempting to use a watch that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watches must be destroyed when no longer useful For consider a local variable of type I watchtype in a subroutine Since the contents of a local variable are lost when the subroutine the watch should be destroyed before returning to the calling program Failure to destroy watches can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watch creates a watch IP o B destroy_watch destroys a watch LP Watches can optionally be given a I in B create_watch This name is used in error messages and B print_watch to identify the watch in the printed output Different applications demand different definitions of time M_StopWatch supports four clocks in each with each clock measuring a different concept of time All of them measure time in seconds IP o user the amount of CPU time used by the user s program IP o sys the amount of CPU time used by the system in support of the user s program IP o cpu the total CPU i user sys IP o wall the wall clock i elapsed real time LP It is not required that all clocks be used A watch can be created with any combination of the four clocks You can also specify a set of I default clocks to be used whenever the clocks are not explicitly determined Since Fortran does not contain an intrinsic function for CPU the implementation of the sys and user clocks is system dependent Some implementations may support only cpu and not user and sys Some implementations may support only wall Since the Fortran standard requires the existence of a B system_clock but does not require that it provide clock it is possible that some implementations might not support wall Clock availability can be determined by B inquiry_stopwatch Unavailable clocks will automatically be removed from the set of default but if a clock that is not available is explicitly a warning message will be generated M_StopWatch supports multiple watches simultaneously Often it is useful to perform the same operation on several watches This is essential for correct operation of B pause_watch and B and can also be convenient for procedures like B and B reset_watch To facilitate M_StopWatch supports the concept of I watch groups When calling a M_StopWatch a watch group can be specified instead of a watch The group is referenced by a variable of type I watchgroup Watch groups must be created before they are used Attempting to use a watch group that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watch groups must be destroyed when no longer useful The watches themselves are not only the grouping of them Failure to destroy watch groups can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watchgroup creates a new watch group IP o B destroy_watchgroup destroys a watch and accept several forms of I watch The forms an array of watches can be specified by an array constructor in the calling for w3 call this can not be used in routines where I watch has intent OUT or intent because the array constructor is actually an not a list of the variables Currently this includes the routines B create_watch and B destroy_watch Most M_StopWatch subroutines take I clock as or or can be an array of such character strings to specify more than one clock Since I clock is always intent an array of clock types can be built with an array constructor note that Fortran requires all character strings in such a construction to have the same length Thus sys and cpu should be padded with a as cpu If the optional argument I clock is the current set of default clocks is used The set of default clocks is set with B option_stopwatch and initially consists of all available clocks A M_StopWatch watch is operated on by subroutine calls that correspond to the actions performed with a common stop watch The basic operation of a watch involves starting stopping and resetting it to IP o B start_watch starts an idle like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B stop_watch stops a running like the Start Stop button on a stop watch IP o B reset_watch sets the clocks on a watch like the Reset button on a stop watch LP Of course

◆ cpu

execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating and destroying local variable watches and groups before returning from a subroutine IP Error occurred while deallocating memory This error occurs if the Fortran B deallocate statement returns a nonzero status while deallocating temporary memory used for an array or group of watches The operation is but be aware that other problems could develop as a result of the deallocate error IP Illegal output form This error occurs in B option_stopwatch or B print_watch if the given print format is not one of the valid the following problems may the character strings in an array constructor must all have the same length Pad three letter clock names with a blank on the right to make a four character for cpu

◆ describes

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME easy to use means of measuring execution time It supports the wall CPU and a breakdown of the CPU clock into user and system times It returns all times in seconds It provides a simple means of determining which clocks are and the precision of those clocks M_StopWatch is used by instrumenting your code with subroutine calls that mimic the operation of a stop watch The primary routines are B and B print_watch M_StopWatch supports multiple and provides the concept of watch groups to allow functions to operate on multiple watches simultaneously SH DESCRIPTION The entities in M_StopWatch that have public accessibility are two derived types and fifteen i must contain the statement use M_stopwatch The derived types but the internals of the type are private Any operations performed on a variable of one of these types must be performed by one of the M_StopWatch subroutines This man page describes

◆ destroy_watchgroup

a watch and accept several forms of I watch The forms an array of watches can be specified by an array constructor in the calling for w3 call this can not be used in routines where I watch has intent OUT or intent because the array constructor is actually an not a list of the variables Currently this includes the routines B create_watch and B destroy_watch Most M_StopWatch subroutines take I clock two depending on whether I watch and I clock are scalars or arrays When measuring CPU it is often desirable to not include the time used by certain parts of the such as printing or graphics In a you might not know which of the clocks are currently so you can not simply stop them before the I O and start them up again after the I O For M_StopWatch provides the pause function IP o B pause_watch temporarily suspend the running watches IP o B end_pause_watch resume suspended watches LP Besides B create_watchgroup and B destroy_watchgroup

TH M_STOPWATCH M_StopWatch M_STOPWATCH OVERVIEW PD SH NAME easy to use means of measuring execution time It supports the wall CPU and a breakdown of the CPU clock into user and system times It returns all times in seconds It provides a simple means of determining which clocks are and the precision of those clocks M_StopWatch is used by instrumenting your code with subroutine calls that mimic the operation of a stop watch The primary routines are B and B print_watch M_StopWatch supports multiple and provides the concept of watch groups to allow functions to operate on multiple watches simultaneously SH DESCRIPTION The entities in M_StopWatch that have public accessibility are two derived types and fifteen i must contain the statement use M_stopwatch The derived types but the internals of the type are private Any operations performed on a variable of one of these types must be performed by one of the M_StopWatch subroutines This man page in general the operations that can be performed by the M_StopWatch subroutines The formal interfaces and detailed descriptions of the routines can be found in the individual man pages A watch is a variable declared to be of type I create_watch before they are used Attempting to use a watch that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watches must be destroyed when no longer useful For consider a local variable of type I watchtype in a subroutine Since the contents of a local variable are lost when the subroutine the watch should be destroyed before returning to the calling program Failure to destroy watches can lead to a memory leak IP o B create_watch creates a watch IP o B destroy_watch destroys a watch LP Watches can optionally be given a I in B create_watch This name is used in error messages and B print_watch to identify the watch in the printed output Different applications demand different definitions of time M_StopWatch supports four clocks in each with each clock measuring a different concept of time All of them measure time in seconds IP o user the amount of CPU time used by the user s program IP o sys the amount of CPU time used by the system in support of the user s program IP o cpu the total CPU i user sys IP o wall the wall clock i elapsed real time LP It is not required that all clocks be used A watch can be created with any combination of the four clocks You can also specify a set of I default clocks to be used whenever the clocks are not explicitly determined Since Fortran does not contain an intrinsic function for CPU the implementation of the sys and user clocks is system dependent Some implementations may support only cpu and not user and sys Some implementations may support only wall Since the Fortran standard requires the existence of a B system_clock but does not require that it provide clock it is possible that some implementations might not support wall Clock availability can be determined by B inquiry_stopwatch Unavailable clocks will automatically be removed from the set of default but if a clock that is not available is explicitly a warning message will be generated M_StopWatch supports multiple watches simultaneously Often it is useful to perform the same operation on several watches This is essential for correct operation of B pause_watch and B and can also be convenient for procedures like B and B reset_watch To facilitate M_StopWatch supports the concept of I watch groups When calling a M_StopWatch a watch group can be specified instead of a watch The group is referenced by a variable of type I watchgroup Watch groups must be created before they are used Attempting to use a watch group that has not been created will generate a Fortran from attempting to pass a pointer with undefined association status to the Fortran intrinsic function B associated Watch groups must be destroyed when no longer useful The watches themselves are not destroyed

destroys a watch LP Watches can optionally be given a I in B create_watch This name is used in error messages and B print_watch to identify the watch in the printed output Different applications demand different definitions of time M_StopWatch supports four clocks in each with each clock measuring a different concept of time All of them measure time in seconds IP o user the amount of CPU time ◆ error

execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating and destroying local variable watches and groups before returning from a subroutine IP Error occurred while deallocating memory This error occurs if the Fortran B deallocate statement returns a nonzero status while deallocating temporary memory used for an array or group of watches The operation is but be aware that other problems could develop as a result of the deallocate error IP Illegal output form This error occurs in B option_stopwatch or B print_watch if the given print format is not one of the valid the following problems may the character strings in an array constructor must all have the same length Pad three letter clock names with a blank on the right to make a four character for and pad watch names so they all have the same watch has intent OUT or so you cannot use an array constructor as an actual argument to construct an array of watches Some compilers will recognize this as a compile time error

◆ example

execution successful IP Watch needs to be created This error occurs if you attempt to use a watch that has been destroyed The watch must first be created again See also the comment about watches that have never been created in the BUGS section IP Watch is in the wrong state for this operation This occurs when you attempt to start a watch that is currently stop a watch that is not etc IP Watch is in an unknown state This occurs if M_StopWatch does not recognize the and indicates an internal bug in M_StopWatch IP Invalid clock type This occurs if I clock is present and one of the specified clocks is not supported by the implementation See BR temporary memory is allocated This error occurs if the Fortran B allocate statement returns a nonzero status indicating that memory could not be allocated Avoid memory leaks by always destroying watches and groups before recreating and destroying local variable watches and groups before returning from a subroutine IP Error occurred while deallocating memory This error occurs if the Fortran B deallocate statement returns a nonzero status while deallocating temporary memory used for an array or group of watches The operation is but be aware that other problems could develop as a result of the deallocate error IP Illegal output form This error occurs in B option_stopwatch or B print_watch if the given print format is not one of the valid the following problems may the character strings in an array constructor must all have the same length Pad three letter clock names with a blank on the right to make a four character for example

◆ expression
